Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Ultrasound-Guided Greater Occipital Nerve Block with Botulinum Toxin for Chronic Occipital Headache

Trial_Design.evidence: The sample size was calculated to detect a 20 mm difference in VAS scores with 80% power and a 0.05 significance level.

Participants.evidence: 54 patients aged 18-85 with chronic occipital headache were randomised into two groups

Intervention.evidence: randomised into two groups: bupivacaine (BUP, n=27) and botulinum toxin (BTX, n=27)

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed the efficacy of ultrasound-guided greater occipital nerve (GON) block using botulinum toxin for chronic occipital headache.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was pain reduction measured by the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) over 24 weeks.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a closed-envelope technique, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 54 patients aged 18-85 with chronic occipital headache were randomised into two groups

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis, with 48 patients completing the study.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The VAS scores at 4, 8, and 24 weeks were significantly lower in the BTX group compared to the BUP group (p<0.05).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.

Trial_Registration.evidence: The trial was registered under number 20110021167

Funding.evidence: funded by Hanyang University Guri Hospital.
